comments:
This course surveys genetics and molecular biology with a strong emphasis on experimental research methods. Students learn about the processes underlying DNA replication and gene expression in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, as well as genetic analysis and genomics. The course also introduces students to technologies that allow researchers to study mechanisms of genetic control in the context of such areas as human disease. In addition to PowerPoint presentations and assigned textbook readings, students are assigned problem sets that expose students to experimental data analysis.

Many students found the course “captivating” and “engaging,” but challenging. Lectures covered a variety of topics and were generally informative and enjoyable. However, one student felt that “there were so many things covered it was hard to really delve into any one of them in a good way.” Some students pointed out that the course was beleaguered by administrative issues, such as difficulties finding announcements about homework assignments, while others complained about the value of recitations and assigned problem sets. Many students also commented about the printability of lecture slides.

This course was co-taught by Professors Gallagher and Bonini. Students described Professor Bonini as “fun,” “passionate” and “captivating.” Some students wished for more organization and focus in her presentations, but most found her lectures interesting and informative. Overall, students were content with the quality of the lectures and felt the background of each professor contributed to the course greatly.

This is a course not designed for introductory students and assumes a basic background in genetics and molecular biology (prerequisites includes either Biol 101, 121 or 91). One student advised, “If you aced BIOL 101/102 then this course will mainly be review, but if you struggled in those then this course will be very difficult.”

This course surveys genetics and molecular biology with a strong emphasis on experimental research methods. Students learn about the processes underlying DNA replication and gene expression in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, as well as genetic analysis and genomics. The course also introduces students to technologies that allow researchers to study mechanisms of genetic control in the context of such areas as human disease. In addition to PowerPoint presentations and assigned textbook readings, students are assigned problem sets that expose students to experimental data analysis.

Many students found the course “captivating” and “engaging,” but challenging. Lectures covered a variety of topics and were generally informative and enjoyable. However, one student felt that “there were so many things covered it was hard to really delve into any one of them in a good way.” Some students complained that the course was beleaguered by a handful of administrative problems, such as difficulties finding announcements about homework assignments, while others complained about the value of recitations and assigned problem sets. Many students also commented about the printability of lecture slides.

This course was co-taught by Professors Gallagher and Bonini. Students described Professor Gallagher as “smooth and flawless” in her lectures. They praised her ability to convey information cohesively, “giving us general mechanisms and explaining details that might be interesting, but emphasizing the important concepts.” Overall, students were content with the quality of the lectures and felt the background of each professor contributed to the course greatly.

This is a course not designed for introductory students and assumes a basic background in genetics and molecular biology (prerequisites includes either Biol 101, 121 or 91). One student advised, “If you aced BIOL 101/102 then this course will mainly be review, but if you struggled in those then this course will be very difficult.”
